stem: A 2-month-old infant presents with tachypnea and a harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. Which physiologic change after birth most increases the left-to-right shunt in this condition?
explanation: As pulmonary vascular resistance falls after birth, left-to-right shunting across the VSD increases, augmenting pulmonary overcirculation and murmur intensity.

stem: A 5-year-old has a fixed split S2 and a systolic ejection murmur best heard at the left upper sternal border. What mechanism explains the murmur?
options: Flow across a restrictive ventricular septal defect
Regurgitant flow through the tricuspid valve
Increased flow across the pulmonic valve
explanation: In secundum ASD, the ejection murmur reflects increased flow across the pulmonic valve; the fixed split S2 is classic due to constant RV stroke volume.

stem: A premature neonate develops a continuous ‘machinery’ murmur at the left infraclavicular area. Which change in oxygen tension normally promotes closure of the ductus arteriosus?
options: Decreased oxygen tension causing smooth muscle relaxation
Increased oxygen tension causing smooth muscle contraction
Increased prostaglandin E2 levels after birth
Increased nitric oxide production in the ductus
Decreased bradykinin levels from the lungs
explanation: Rising arterial oxygen tension after birth leads to ductal smooth muscle constriction and functional closure; prostaglandins maintain patency in utero.

stem: A 6-day-old presents with poor feeding and lethargy. Exam shows cool lower extremities and weak femoral pulses. Which physiology best explains this presentation in a ductal-dependent coarctation?
options: Sudden decrease in pulmonary blood flow when pulmonary vascular resistance falls
Systemic hypoperfusion due to ductal closure reducing descending aortic flow
Right-to-left shunt at the atrial level increasing systemic saturation
Increased LV preload due to increased pulmonary venous return
Acute rise in systemic vascular resistance due to prostaglandin infusion
explanation: When the ductus closes in critical coarctation, flow to the descending aorta falls, causing systemic hypoperfusion and shock; prostaglandin E1 can reopen the ductus.

stem: A 3-month-old with cyanosis has a harsh systolic murmur. Which change will DECREASE right-to-left shunting during a hypercyanotic spell?
explanation: Knee-to-chest maneuvers raise systemic vascular resistance, reducing the right-to-left shunt across the VSD and improving oxygenation.

stem: A term neonate has profound cyanosis within hours of birth that does not respond to oxygen. Chest X-ray shows an "egg-on-a-string" heart. What immediate intervention improves mixing?
explanation: Prostaglandin E1 maintains ductal patency and augments mixing in D-TGA while preparing for balloon atrial septostomy and arterial switch.

stem: A 1-week-old with tachypnea and a single loud S2 is found to have a truncus arteriosus. Which finding is most expected on echocardiography?
options: Two separate semilunar valves with a subaortic VSD
A single arterial trunk overriding a large VSD
Severe subpulmonic stenosis with overriding aorta
Atrioventricular septal defect with common AV valve
A large secundum ASD with no VSD
explanation: Truncus has a single arterial trunk with a large VSD supplying systemic, pulmonary, and coronary circulations; S2 is single/loud.

stem: A neonate with cyanosis and respiratory distress has snowman (figure-8) sign on chest X-ray. Which is required for survival before repair?
options: Patent foramen ovale must be closed
explanation: Systemic and pulmonary venous blood must mix via an atrial communication to sustain cardiac output in TAPVR.

stem: An infant with Down syndrome has a common atrioventricular valve and large primum ASD with inlet VSD. Which complication develops earliest without repair?
explanation: Large left-to-right shunt can rapidly increase pulmonary blood flow and pressure, leading to early pulmonary vascular disease in complete AV canal.

stem: A cyanotic neonate with a massively enlarged right atrium has a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. Which mechanism most explains cyanosis?
options: Right-to-left shunt at atrial level due to severe TR
explanation: Severe tricuspid regurgitation and atrialization of the RV elevate RA pressure, driving right-to-left shunting across an atrial communication.

stem: A 9-year-old with exercise-induced leg fatigue and headaches has upper-extremity hypertension and diminished femoral pulses. Which exam finding is most characteristic?
options: Continuous machinery murmur at left infraclavicular area
Systolic murmur over the back between the scapulae
explanation: In discrete juxtaductal coarctation, a systolic murmur is often heard over the left infrascapular area due to turbulent flow across the narrowed segment.

stem: In tetralogy of Fallot, which feature primarily determines the intensity of the systolic murmur?
options: Size of the ventricular septal defect
Severity of right ventricular outflow obstruction
Presence of an atrial septal defect
Size of the patent ductus arteriosus
explanation: The murmur intensity correlates with the degree of RV outflow tract obstruction (crescendo–decrescendo at LUSB), not the VSD size.
